results.title: Project out of school: planning a quality service
results.creator_credit: Alex Jaye, Suzanne Cecil-Fizdale, Maryla Juchnowski and Video Media Production
results.brief_description: Provides the considerations for planning quality out of school programs both before and after school. Shows a number of active programs, emphasises the advantages of holding such programs, and illustrates ways of involving parents, children and staff. Appropriate for Professional Development and Personal Development (Home Economics) at VCE level

results.title: Project grizzly
results.creator_credit: Peter Lynch, Michael Allder and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: Troy Hurtubise on 18th May 2002, once again made the news with a demonstration of his latest grizzly bear suit ‘Ursus Mark VII’. ‘Project grizzly’ documents his story. Troy Hurtubise’s obsession was given birth to over 10 years ago when he was confronted by a grizzly bear whilst trekking alone in the Canadian wilderness. Under an extraordinary set of circumstances the grizzly spares Troy’s life and so an obsession is born. The task Troy set himself is to build a suit that will withstand an attack from a grizzly bear. The mission is to again confront ‘Old Man’ (Troy’s name for the grizzly) whilst wearing the suit to continue his “close quarter bear research”. After $150,000 has been spent and 6 proto-types later Troy takes us through the joys and tribulations of his experimentation whilst admitting that he suffers from claustrophobia. By the end of the documentary we see Troy in suit being bashed with base-ball bats, lead balls and hit by a 3-tonne truck travelling at 50km/h - 18 times! So will Troy get his sniff of ‘Old Man’ or will the transport of the suit impede the project? Also shown is a reconstructed Ska-Nah-Doht, a traditional Iroquoian village.

results.title: Project for plenty
results.creator_credit: V.R. Sarma, M Bilavaana and Documentary Films of India
results.brief_description: A report on the building of the Hirakud Dam, one of the schemes undertaken by the government of India to develop the country’s potential resources. The film illustrates building activity at the actual dam site and the dykes and canals which are being constructed to harness the waters of the Mahanadi River and bring new highways, bridges, rail-line, electricity, thriving townships and prosperity to a valley and its people.
results.creator_credit_for_label: V.R. Sarma, M Bilavaana and Documentary Films of India

results.title: Project for all seasons
results.creator_credit: Jim White and Canadian International Development Agency
results.brief_description: describes a project funded by Canada and the World Bank to aid agriculture, grazing and road building in Africa. The project also built an administration centre and a town of 85 houses. They helped to provide employment so that their menfolk working down mines in South Africa could return home.

results.title: Project expansion
results.creator_credit: Robert Walker, Ross Wood and Ross Wood Productions
results.brief_description: A major expansion program, begun by New Broken Hill Consolidated Ltd, in 1968, was completed in 1971. The film describes the expansion activities, which included the sinking of a three-thousand foot air shaft and major extensions to the underground workings. Many views of modern mining methods are provided. Could be used for geography, secondary social studies, and for general interest.

results.title: Project 500 Kv
results.brief_description: Tells the story of the stringing of high voltage cables across the Gippsland countryside. Working with electric line transmissions oat half a million volts is difficult work and both the testing of the apparatus and the building of the towers and lines provide many spectacular scenes.

results.title: Project 074
results.creator_credit: Shell Film Unit and Peter De Normanville
results.brief_description: The standard method of measuring engine wear is to weigh a piston ring before and after a long period of running. A far less laborious procedure makes use of a radio-active piston ring; radiating particles worn from the ring circulate in the lubricating oil, and their abundance, which can be accurately measured, gives a practically instantaneous indication of engine wear. All this is explained in this film, and views of the Harwell atomic pile are also shown.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Shell Film Unit and Peter De Normanville

results.title: Progressive waves: transverse & longitudinal
results.brief_description: Introduces the subject of transverse progressive waves by Illustrating a pulse being sent down a stretched rope. Shows its velocity of travel to be dependent upon the elastic and inertial factors. Employs a stretched string to show steady waves train propagation, and identifies and relates waves length and frequency. Longitudinal wave disturbance is shown by a pulse moving down a row of beads connected by light-weight strings.
